description: This course will provide an introduction to computation and data analysis using MATLAB - an industry standard programming and visualization environment. The course will cover the fundamentals of computing including: variables, functions, flow control, iteration and recursion. These concepts will be illustrated through examples and assignments which show how computing is applied to various scientific and engineering problems. Examples will be drawn from the simulation of physical and chemical systems, the analysis of experimental data, Monte Carlo numerical experiments, image and audio processing, and control of sensors and actuators. This course does not assume any prior programming experience but will make use of basic concepts from calculus and Newtonian physics.
name: INTRO SCIENTIFIC COMP

values.comments:
This course provides an introduction to computation and data analysis using MATLAB - an industry standard programming and visualization environment. The course covers the fundamentals of computing including: variables, functions, flow control, iteration and recursion. These concepts are illustrated through examples and assignments which show how computing is applied to various scientific and engineering problems. Examples are drawn from the simulation of physical and chemical systems, the analysis of experimental data, Monte Carlo numerical experiments, image and audio processing, and control of sensors and actuators. This course does not assume any prior programming experience but will make use of basic concepts from calculus and Newtonian physics.

Overall, students felt that the course was heavily mathematics-oriented, and many reported spending a lot of time learning mathematical theory. For those with no prior programming experience, it seemed at times like Professor Dietz was lecturing to an audience of experienced programmers. However, many students reported learning a lot and becoming accustomed to the professor’s teaching style after a few weeks.

Students seemed to agree that Professor Dietz was “very, very enthusiastic about programming, computers, and MATLAB” and that he tried to get all of the students to share in her excitement. Many felt that she was always available to help students finish their projects and answer questions. Several felt that the professor intentionally made the course easy to understand so that it was not hard for new programmers to learn. 

Students generally believed that the curriculum tended to be haphazard and unfocused, and students learned a variety of seemingly random things. Some reported that projects were designed to avoid making students feel stuck or frustrated. Course projects and assessments were described as “fair” and stimulated interest among students to continue studying MATLAB.
